case_title: ABDUL QAYYUM AWAN vs DIRECTOR GENERAL ANTI-CORRUPTION and others
reference_no_or_id: Application for partial suspension of the impugned Notification dated 18.5.2016
court: Azad Jammu and Kashmir Service Tribunal

accussed_details.name: Abdul Qayyum Awan
allegation: Incorrect date of birth entry in service record

complaint_summary: The appellant was retired from service via Notification dated 18.05.2016, with instructions to recover salary and benefits received after 04.08.2015 due to alleged incorrect date of birth entry in service records.
investigation_summary: The appellant applied for correction of his date of birth based on his Identity Card and matriculation certificate. The application was rejected by the departmental authority on 14.11.2014. Subsequent appeals were filed, leading to conflicting judgments by the Service Tribunal and the apex Court.
judgment_summary: The Tribunal suspended the impugned Notification dated 18.05.2016 to the extent of recovery of salary and benefits drawn after 04.08.2015, citing legal precedents that disallow recovery of salary for services rendered post-retirement due to litigation.
legal_arguments: Recovery of salary post-retirement is unjustified as the appellant rendered services during the litigation period.
Legal precedents establish that salary drawn during such periods cannot be recovered.
key_issues: Validity of recovery of salary post-retirement
Correction of date of birth in service records
Application of legal precedents in service disputes

maxims.Equity: No one should be unjustly enriched at the expense of another.

legal_terms.Superannuation: The age at which a person is required to retire from service.
legal_terms.Pensionary Benefits: Benefits received by a retired employee.

words_and_phrases.Impugned Notification: The notification being challenged in the appeal.

summary_vector_notes: The case involves a dispute over recovery of salary drawn post-retirement due to litigation over correction of date of birth. The Tribunal suspended the recovery citing legal precedents that disallow penalizing employees for services rendered during litigation.
